Less than one minute in: "here's a 1MT bomb which we're going to use as the basis for our considerations since there are bigger bombs than that"

REALITY CHECK: very few bombs in any nation's arsenal are over 20kt, for the simple reason that they're wasteful unless striking extremely-hardened targets (ala Cheyenne Mountain). Bigger nukes were used during the early Cold War (1950s/60s) for one reason: targeting and missile accuracy for intercontinental strikes were measured not in meters and yards but kilometers and miles. "If you can't hit the nail, use a bigger hammer".

Note that this means a nuclear war with CHINA - which has long-range rockets that are inaccurate - could still involve megaton-scale bombs. But a war with Russia would be almost entirely devoid of such weapons.

A 1MT bomb is NOT "much smaller than many modern nuclear weapons". The average yield of the US's stockpile is 0.2MT. It's largest active-use bomb today is the B83 with a yield of 1.2MT. Most weapons in the world arsenal have a smaller yield than this, because most high-yield weapons that existed in the past have been dismantled.

Those "studies" fail to take into account the fact that "nuclear winter" is a farce which has been repeatedly debunked. See, we have this atmospheric layer called the Tropopause. It's natural barrier between the Troposphere (where we live and weather happens) and the Stratosphere (the upper atmosphere). Nuclear winter assumes that smoke from burning cities can magically breach this barrier on its own and remain suspended in the Stratosphere for weeks and months, blocking the sun. Something even the strongest and most severe storms, with the strongest updrafts, can't do. It takes a great deal of force to drive something past the Tropopause and into the Stratosphere. Megaton range nuclear weapons can do it, but only with whatever material gets sucked into the mushroom cloud. But even detonating every nuke on the planet would not put enough material into the Stratosphere to block out the sun for weeks and months. Burning cities an forests have zero chance. Volcanoes can do it, and have. But only to a degree, and very localized. In fact, the only force powerful enough to cause this "nuclear winter" would be a large meteor impact, like the event theorized to have killed of the dinosaurs. That's not exactly a nuclear event, and frankly far exceeds what humans can do with their cute little bombs.

This video is so full of BS. Of the 15,000 nuclear weapons in the world most are waiting to be dismantled or sitting on shelves and are nothing more then expensive paper weights. There are very few, if any capable weapons in the Megaton Range (the Chinese have a few dozen in caves that were made in the 70's aimed at Russia). The average yeild of all of the "deployed" Russian nukes in 2017, (about 1800 warheads) it's 340Kt (Kilotons) and the "deployed" US average yield (about 2300 warheads) is 215Kt.

The India/Pakistan engagement is also BS. We had many Nuke tests in the Pacific and in the US back in the 50's were many nukes were detonated one after the other and resulted in several times the release of what a full scale India/Pakiatan engagement would be during each test sequence.

Don't get me wrong, Nukes = really bad day. Worst ever. But these completely disingenuous fear mongering videos for the sake of sensationalism, and a few million hits, piss me off.

This video fails to take into account the reason for nuclear weapons.

That reason is destruction.

In order to get said destruction they need be air burst over a target so long as that target is above ground air bursts do not send up radioactive particulates, which is what black rain and fallout is, compared to the ground explosions which do.

90% of all nuclear detonations in a nuclear war will be air burst detonations because that is simply how they cause the most destruction and how they are most effectively used on a militarily strategic level.

What an air burst does do however is send up most of the deadly radiation high into the atmosphere where it dissipates harmlessly and doesnt create a fallout effect.

Compared with the atom bombs dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki our fusion and fission weapons are much cleaner in terms of radiation created.

Even then when compared to the weapons we had during the height of the cold war our weapons now are still smaller, less radioactive, and more accurate.

Its why the US stopped making our bombs bigger. We instead went with smaller "cleaner" more accurate warheads that will cause more accurate damage than their larger lesser accurate russian and chinese counterparts.


Now all this being said even with 10 of the 100 nuclear weapons being ground explosions thats still a significant amount of radioactive earth being thrown up into the atmosphere, while more than likely no where near enough to cause what that study suggested, its still going to suck for at least a year or two.

Also for those people worried about North Korea think of it this way.

Your on at one end of a football field NK's at the other.

They have a bow and arrow.

You have a modern sniper rifle.

They fire first the arrow sailing wide left and missing you completely.

You retaliate by sending a bullet the size of the first index on your pointer finger through their skull.

The lecture failed to mention several other effects.
1. Fires - Fires will burn out of control and with no water pressure fire fighters will not be able to stop them.
2. Loss of municipal services - This mean no electricity, water services, sanitation, gas, police, fire, trash pickup etc.
3. Loss of communication - No TV, radio, internet, cell phones, morse code, carrier pigeons, pony express.
4. Loss of health services - No hospitals, clinics, medicine, band aides, etc
5. Loss of resources - No grocery stores, Dept stores, malls, all kinds of stuff in general.
6. Loss of government services - No mail, no social services, no welfare, no uncle Sam

This short list does not sufficiently describe such an event. But I just wanted to put a human face on it and not simply describe it as a mathematical equation.

Let's talk about Strontium-90.

Strontium-90 is a radioactive isotope of Strontium produced by nuclear fission. It has a decay rate of -2.44% per year, with a half-life of 28.8 years. It's a destructive component of nuclear fallout, brought up by Jake Roper in Vsauce3's video on this subject.

This is only one example of an isotope in nuclear fallout which will not decay to 1% in terms of radioactivity by the end of two weeks. Though the claim is made in this video and the one on AsapTHOUGHT, I don't think that it's fair to say that after two weeks, it's safe to roam an area where nuclear fallout has fallen. I think decades is a better estimate.

It's always a good idea to present nuclear war in the worst possible terms, even though an actual nuclear war would likely not be as dire as presented for a number of reason. The first good reason not to detonate a nuke over populated areas is because it's a waste of a perfectly good and expensive weapon. The detonation of three or four nukes in low orbit would render all electronics below the blasts useless. Without electronics, all communication halts, transportation halts, everything stops. In six weeks people in large population centers will be eating each other. The population of an affected area becomes more of a concern than the enemy that launched the weapon. Result: victory with the use of four weapons vice 100. Furthermore, expensive infrastructure remains in tact allowing an invading army to use it.
Once the "button" gets pushed, that's it. Everything changes. Death, disease, starvation, misery... Not fun. I think people need to grow up... Like for example, the POTUS. Grow up Trump!

So just a couple of factual errors. Nobody has very large, 5+ megaton weapons in their arsenal anymore. At one time both the US and Soviet Union had a fair number of weapons in the 10-25 megaton weapons (100 megaton Czar Bombas were never actually deployed, only tested to show who had the biggest d***). Today, as delivery systems have become much more accurate, the requirement for large weapons has disappeared so most strategic nuclear weapons are sub megaton size (though Russia and the US continue to have some megaton class weapons, 1-3 megaton or so).

Both the US and Russia have MIRV missiles, with anywhere from 3-10+ weapons per missile, but these weapons are typically well below a megaton in yield.

1. Nuclear winter has been debunked https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nuclear_winter#Criticism_and_debate2. Most bombs will be airbursts to maximize the blast force which will minimize fallout. Ground burst would only be used on underground targets (bunkers, missile silos, etc)3. Most nuclear bombs are under 500K, as the bigger bombs required heavier lift systems (bombers, or ICMBs). Large single bombs are less effective than MIRV ICBMs and bombers, since more targets can be hit with more bombs for a given delivery vehicle Payload. most ICBMs are MIRVs which a single ICBM carriers a dozen or more warheads that can strike many targets.4. The big problem is not the bombs but the worlds 440+ nuclear reactors which would fail and meltdown as the grid is lost and the ability to service & maintain them is lost. A typical nuclear bomb has fissile material measured in kilograms, and a typical nuclear reactor has fissile material measured in tons. Its likely that in a global nuclear war the reactors will kill off humanity and not the bombs. Most of the nuclear reactors are adjacent to the rivers and oceans since they use large amounts of water. When these reactors fail they will contaminate the rivers and oceans, perhaps to the point no human life can exist. or to the point humans are forced to live in very isolated pockets.
Pro advice: Move as far away from large cities as possible. And/or possibly even to different countries, that are less likely to be targeted.

Those two nukes the US dropped on Japan probably prevented a nuclear war. Dig this: it was a real world display of what a nuclear bomb could do. If the US and its allies won regardless, after WW2, countries would have still developed their own nukes eventually. The public would not have seen the power of the nuke as it would all really be a theoretical concept and there wouldn't be the idea around that these things can do some real damage thus much less public outcry to not use nukes in war.

So, you start tossing nukes while other countries have nukes and next thing you know, global thermonuclear war.

I think a real world example prevented this thus far. It isn't to say it won't happen some day, but it pushed it back, at least.

One thing people forget to put into their equations on a nuclear war/bomb blast is the numbers of nuclear power plants and nuclear waste storage facilities. The facilities and plants will massively amplify the fallout material and radioactive particulates.
For instance, they will rate plants, shelters, and nuclear waste storage facilities by saying things like "__ can survive a direct blast from nuclear bomb" but they do not mention how a second , or even a series of bombs, moments after will annihilate these structures.

Now... this estimation of all the 400+ nuclear power plants, and the countless tons of nuclear waste in the northern hemisphere, a series of blast will render the planet uninhabitable for centuries. The 30-year rule is only for certain minor aspects and is a myth in this day and age. It would only take less than 5 consecutive direct blasts to Yucca Mountain in the US to penetrate and then force the waste within it into the atmosphere. This alone could destroy all humanity in the northern hemisphere within a few months as well as create a domino effect of other nuclear plants going into a meltdown stage over time.

Long story short... nothing will survive a full on strategic nuclear war. Humanity will likely not survive a large amount of large scale disasters due to the numbers of nuclear power plants on the planet. "The world still possesses around 10,000 nuclear warheads, overwhelmingly in Russia and the US. But let’s assume these two nations do not press the button, and that tensions eventually explode between India and Pakistan....The two countries have just over 200 relatively small nuclear warheads between them. Suppose they unleash half of them, a hundred 15-kilotonne weapons the size of Little Boy...The carnage from the blast, as well as firestorms and radiation in megacities like Karachi and Delhi, would kill millions...The fires would send about 5 million tonnes of hot black smoke into the stratosphere, where it would spread round the world. This smog would cut solar radiation reaching Earth’s surface by 8 per cent – enough to drop average winter temperatures by a startling 2.5 to 6 °C across North America, Europe and much of Asia, and not just for a few days. It would take around five years for the impacts to peak, and the repercussions would still be felt strongly after a decade.
Besides a nuclear winter, climate models predict that rainfall would be reduced as weather systems lost energy. The Asian monsoon would collapse: that’s two billion people with as much as 80 per cent less water. The Amazon basin and the already arid Southwestern US and western Australia would scarcely do better.
The smoke would heat the normally chilly stratosphere by around 30 °C, unleashing nitrogen chemistry that would destroy much of the ozone layer. But skin cancer might be the least of our concerns. Near-ice-age temperatures would cause frosts capable of reducing the growing season in the world’s mid-latitude bread baskets by up to 40 days. This, combined with meagre rainfall and blistering UV, would cause crop yields to plummet. Nuclear winter would deliver global famine.
All this, remember, from a small regional war. Steven Starr of the University of Missouri has calculated that a nuclear exchange between the US and Russia could throw 150 million tonnes of smoke into the air. That would block 70 per cent of sunlight and cool much of the world by 20 °C or more. Unable to grow food, most people would starve to death."
-New Scientist, 16 Nov 2016

Why doesn't this video mention mutually assured destruction? The concept is relatively simple: if one side fires nukes, the other will dump nukes, and both sides will cease to exist completely. Thus neither side dares use nuclear weapons so long as the other side has nukes too. If a disarmament is agreed between two or more nations, the other side may secretly keep nuclear weapons, hidden, and a side that actually disarms themselves no-longer rely on mutually assured destruction to deter a nuclear threat.

Coming from a military man who has gone to school to learn about Nuclear, Biological, and Chemical warfare I wanted to take a moment to chime in and reassure people whose comments show they have been freaked out by this video. True, there are roughly 20,000 active nuclear warheads in the world, but these scenarios are worst case if they were all used at once and produced a maximum yield. Truth is, most nuclear warheads are not strategic, city destroying, mega warheads, or MIRV cluster bombs like the Russian SS-18 or U.S. MX; they number only in the dozens. Most are tactical nukes that have yields of less than 1000 kilotons for use to be directed against battlefield targets like enemy airfields, warship ports, oil fields, command centers, and nuclear launch sites. Most nuclear bombs today produce only 1% of the energy released from the Hiroshima bomb, and are able to blow up a battlefield roughly the size of a football stadium. A single volcano releases an equivalent of 100,000 nuclear warheads of energy; yet humanity has survived multiple volcanos in our lifetimes. Remember the eruption of Mount Eyjafjallajokull in Iceland in 2010? That single volcano blew off more energy than almost all the nukes the world ever produced. It blotted out all of Europe with smoke for months; I was stationed in Kuwait at the time and I saw the haze reach the Middle East right over me. During World War 2, the Allied bombing campaigns of Dresden, Germany, and Tokyo, Japan by conventional bombs killed more people in each city than the Hiroshima and Nagasaki bombs combined. Nuclear weapons are powerful, and devastating, but the llikelihood that in a war you will be killed by one is remote. During our lifetimes we will have 1000s of times more chances to be killed in a car accident than a nuclear war. The danger is there, but I wouldn't obsess about it if I were you.

Hi all.  I'm 44 years old. Back in the 1980's (when I was 13), there was a high probability that nuclear war would break out, so much so that the Bulletin of Atomic Scientists would drag out the Doomsday Clock every week or so and remind us all how close we are to certain doom (the clock still exists, BTW). We didn't know who would start it, or how big it would be, but the paranoia of a nuclear event was so high that many, many post-apocalyptic made-for-TV movies came out and scared the living shit out of my 13 year old psyche.  I'm starting to get that same terror again.  Ugh.  Good luck, everyone.

Multi-megaton warheads were mostly an artifact of the 50s and 60s - a combination of the delivery system vulnerability and inaccuracy. (You can shoot down 99 out of a hundred bombers, but it that one only gets within five miles of the target, destruction is assured.) As missiles became more accurate and electronics shrunk there was a shift to lower yield. Most modern weapons are in the 250-350 kiloton range. Of course, ICBMs can carry more than one warhead and these are still 10-20 times the WWII weapons yield.
